div.h2: Death is not separate from living

span.p: The talk is about ending attachment. K talks about ending attachment, which means death. When we die we lose all attachment, and the question is can we end attachment while living.
K doesn't provide answers by through dialog invites you to look at the question at hand.

div.h2: Psychologically there is no future

span.p: Do you keep procrastinating, because you think tomorrow will be different, or you will muster the courage to do something you are not doing today.
This talk by Krishnamurthy guides you to really look at this question.

div.h2: Never run from sorrow
div.span: K starts with looking at what is suffering, and some of the signs of suffering which are aggression, suppression and other conditions that define our lives that cause sorrow. He then asks, is it possible to be free of sorrow. He always comes back to the theme of self centered thought as the cause of suffering.

div.h2: A different kind of energy

span.div: Krishnamurti discusses the importance of a unique kind of energy, distinct from physical energy, needed for personal and societal transformation.

div.span: He points out that conventional energy often comes from conflict, friction, and competition, which can be destructive.
Krishnamurti emphasizes the search for an energy unrelated to religious dogma, rituals, or beliefs and highlights the limitations of thought-based energy.
He suggests that true transformation requires a deep understanding of consciousness and transcending its content.
Krishnamurti argues against traditional meditation methods and advocates for genuine awareness and the cessation of thought as a means to access a new quality of energy.

div.h2: Do We Have Free Will? Common Sense, Moral Responsibility & the Meaning of Life

span.div: The discussion revolves around the concept of free will and its various views.

div.span: Noam Chomsky points out that people, including those who deny free will, often act as if they believe in it.
Science, according to Chomsky, cannot provide conclusive answers on free will, leaving two possibilities: either humans are deluded or there's something missing in human science.
The conversation touches on linguistics and the challenges of understanding the relationship between language and thought.

Chomsky emphasizes the importance of questioning whether there is a "mind-body problem" in philosophy before attempting to solve it, asserting that it doesn't exist, as recognized by Isaac Newton and John Locke.

div.h2: The man who meditated for 25 years
div.span: Krishnamurti shares a dialog with a man who spent 25 years of his life in solitude and meditation, and his conclusion after listening to a talk by K was that he recognized he lived 25 years in illusion. K then talks about the step to end confusion!

div.h2: Dr. Gabor Maté on trauma, addiction, and illness under capitalism

p.span: Dr. Gabor Maté joins The Chris Hedges Report to discuss his new book, The Myth of Normal: Trauma, Illness and Healing in a Toxic Culture.

span.p: Dr. Gabor Mate's new book argues that consumer society's definition of normal is at war with basic human needs, leading to chronic disorders and self-annihilation.
He discusses the concept of being in the grip of a distant past that prevents us from inhabiting the present moment.

[00:01 Dr. Gabor Mate's new book argues that consumer society's definition of normal is at war with basic human needs, leading to severe damage to our psyches and pushing us towards self-annihilation.
- Consumer society rewards psychopathic traits and fosters chronic disorders.
- The cult of the self leads to personal and social self-annihilation.
- The past colors our present, and trauma from early childhood governs our behaviors in adulthood.
[04:51] Childhood trauma can lead to a fractured sense of self.
- Children absorb the stresses of their parents, which can impact their nervous systems.
- Not meeting a child's essential need to be seen and accepted can also cause trauma.
[08:53] Childhood trauma leads to disconnection and fracturing of the self, resulting in addiction and shame-based view of oneself.
- Childhood trauma causes disconnection from the self and leads to addiction as a coping mechanism.
- Shame-based view of oneself is a result of trauma and leads to addiction as a way to soothe the pain.
- Society's pressures and distractions reinforce trauma and disconnection from the self.
[13:11] Consumer society creates false needs
- People confuse desires with needs, especially addicts and children
- Society draws attention away from what's important and makes us believe trivial things are essential
[17:29] Trauma is passed down unconsciously and affects our behavior
- Childhood trauma can lead to unconscious recreation of similar scenarios in adulthood
- Unresolved trauma can lead to addictive behavior and affect relationships with loved ones
[20:52] Emotions and stress can cause and worsen diseases
- Science has shown a link between emotions and diseases since the 1800s
- Long-term stress can suppress the immune system and cause autoimmune diseases
[24:33] Chronic illness is linked to certain character traits.
- Chronic illness patients have an automatic regard for others' emotional needs, rigid identification with duty and responsibilities, repression of healthy anger, and two fatal beliefs.
- These traits impose tremendous stress on individuals, leading to illness. Repressed anger diverts body energy, wearing on the immune and nervous systems.
[28:18] Attachment and authenticity are essential for human survival and well-being.
- Children are wired for attachment and without it, there is no life.
- Authenticity involves being in touch with our feelings and acting on them, but toxic parenting advice often teaches parents to ignore their instincts and suppress their children's natural emotions.

div.h2: Don’t Worry, Everything is Out of Control

span.p: The video describes how ancient Taoist philosophers believed that people's desire to control and alter natural processes leads to stress and worry.
They encouraged letting go of this desire and letting nature take its course, as well as letting go of existing concepts and worldviews and becoming aware of emptiness.
The goal of this is to live an easier life with less worry, and to follow Tao, the universal principle.
The video suggests that these ancient ideas can be used as antidotes for reducing worry in a world that often feels out of control.

div.h2: To be aware of our past

span.p: Krishnamurti is unlike any other teacher you have come across. He comes to you as someone with no philosophy or agenda. Someone who has looked deeply into the human condition and uses his presentations to invite people to think about the whole problem of existence.

In this talk you will observe Krishnamurti in his essence and are invited to look into the problem of existence and examine how we can be free to observe the whole issue if existence without any distortion.

div.h2: Meditation is not a practice
div.span: Krishnamurti asks why is it necessary to meditate at all. Then he gets in the meaning of the word and shares that meditation also means measure! The dialog is about living a life without comparison and measurement

div.h2: Why does the mind demand pleasure? Saanen 1967

span.p: Krishnamurti says we are not serious about what matters in life and are more serious about mundane stuff.
Listen to hear what he means and explore together. He says that caring about serious topics in life gives one vitality and energy.

div.h2: Great interview of Dr. David Suzuki with Dr. David Bohm, physicist, colleague of Dr. Albert Einstein

span.div: David Bohm discusses his interest in theoretical physics, including nuclear physics, plasma, and the fundamental theories of physics. He mentions the uncertainty and contradictions in these theories and the challenge of analyzing particles.
[00:22] Physics faces challenges in understanding the nature of matter and the contradictions between quantum mechanics and relativity.
- Particles can behave like waves, making analysis difficult.
- The search for fundamental building blocks of the universe has been elusive.
- The concept of local properties of particles breaks down in quantum mechanics.
- Physicists often ignore these problems and focus on calculations.
[05:54] Relativity and quantum theory both agree that the universe is made up of undivided wholeness.
- Relativity sees particles as concentrated regions of a general field that merge with others, while quantum mechanics sees energy as indivisible quant
- Both theories agree on the interconnectedness of the observed and the observer, including atoms and humans.
[10:53] Matter is not an external object that passes through space, but rather a manifestation of a deeper implicit order.
- Objects that seem to exist independently are actually interconnected manifestations of this deeper order.
- An analogy of a folded and unfolded droplet in glycerin helps explain the behavior of particles and illustrates the presence of an unmanifest order.
[16:08] Quantum mechanics describes particles as unfolding and manifesting in a continuous process.
- The fundamental properties of matter move in an order of unfoldment.
- A particle in quantum mechanics is present in the whole and unfolds to manifest as a separate thing.
- The entire universe is unfolding, explaining the peculiar effects of quantum mechanics.
- Different environments can cause particles to unfold in different ways, like a wave or a particle.
- Mathematics in quantum mechanics describes the behavior of particles as both waves and particles.
- Research is being done to develop a mathematical extension to make a visual representation of quantum mechanics.
- The scientific community has varying responses to this approach.
[20:49] Science alone cannot solve the problems of mankind. (Explains his relationship with Krishnamurti and relationship of Religion and Science)
- Interest in science is not separate from religion or philosophy.
- Science has caused problems and made things worse.
- A deeper understanding of ourselves is needed to approach these problems.
- Thought itself is conditioned and irrational, leading to disorder and confusion.
[25:28] Self-deception is a major component of human thought.
- Desire creates self-deception and leads to irrationalities.
- People believe anything that aids their supreme values.
- Observing our relationships and feelings can help us become aware of our programming.
[29:54] Recognizing the connection between thought and bodily sensations
- Fear, anger, pleasure, pain, and sorrow are reflections of our inner program
- Psychotherapy focuses on analyzing past incidents, while self-reflection looks inward
- Accepting and understanding our emotions is key to changing our programming
[34:14] The source of global force is the same as individual collective programs that need to be changed.
- Efforts by religion, science, and politics have failed to create real change.
- The root of the problem lies within society, which is the totality of individuals.
- The problem cannot be directly affected and is like Niagara Falls, going on its own way.
- If a considerable number of individuals remove themselves from the problem, they can think together and divert it to something less dangerous.
- A small number of people can give a tremendous impetus to society.
- Civilizations start with a few people with high energy, but they decline when traditions accumulate and brain cells fill up with programs.
- Very few leaders have any energy and simply repeat the same old story.
- New ideas with higher energy and relevance to actual problems are needed to divert us from impending disaster.

div.h2: David Bohm on Krishnamurti and the problem of thought.

span.div: David Bohm points out that Krishnamurthy distinguishes between rational, valuable thought (e.g., in sciences) and self-centered thought, which is problematic. Here is an overview of what is discussed.
- Self-centered thought revolves around an illusory self and distorts understanding of everything.
- Defense mechanisms protect the illusion of self; threats trigger powerful responses to preserve it.
- Krishnamurthy claims self is not the source of thought; rather, thought generates a concept of self.
- The purpose of Krishnamurthy's work is to liberate humanity from self-centered conditioning for genuine creative growth.

div.h2: The Purpose of Education

div.span: Chomsky discusses two different concepts of education: one that comes from the Enlightenment and emphasizes inquiry and creativity, and another that focuses on indoctrination and control.

span.div: ## Two Concepts of Education
- The traditional interpretation of education from the Enlightenment emphasizes inquiry and creativity.
- Another concept of education is indoctrination, which aims to place young people into a framework where they follow orders, accept existing frameworks, and not challenge authority.
- There are powerful structures in society that prefer people to be indoctrinated conformists who do not ask too many questions or try to shake systems of power and authority.
- People have to make choices about what kind of educational system they want: one that encourages inquiry or one that promotes conformity.
# Technological Changes in Society
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about how technological changes have impacted society over time.
## Impact of Technological Changes

- While there has been significant growth in new technology such as communication, information access, and interchange, it probably does not compare with the impact of technological advances from a century ago.
- For example, the shift from a sailing vessel to a telegraph had an extraordinary impact on communication between England and the United States.
# Technology and Education

Section Overview: In this section, Noam Chomsky discusses the role of technology in education. He explains that technology is neutral and can be used for good or bad depending on how it is used. He also emphasizes the importance of having a clear framework when using technology to pursue any kind of inquiry.
## The Neutrality of Technology
- Technology is neutral like a hammer; it can be used for good or bad.
- The internet is valuable if you know what you're looking for and have a framework of understanding that directs you to particular things.
- Exploring the internet without a clear framework is just picking out random factoids that don't mean anything.
## Importance of Having a Clear Framework
- You need a relatively clear framework directing your search to pursue any kind of inquiry.
- Cultivating the capacity to seek what's significant while always being willing to question whether you're on the right track is crucial.
- Behind any significant use of contemporary technology, there must be some well-constructed directive conceptual apparatus; otherwise, it's unlikely to be helpful.
# Education as Human Development

Section Overview: In this section, Noam Chomsky talks about education as human development. He argues that an educational system should aim at creating better human beings rather than just increasing GDP.
## Value of Education
- An education system should aim at creating better human beings because that's what an educational system should be for.
- An education system that helps create free creative independent individuals who appreciate and gain from cultural achievements is valuable in itself regardless of its impact on society.
## The Cost and Benefits of Technology
- The new technology was developed in the public sector, where people were exploring new possibilities that were mostly unthought of at the time.
- Scientific and cultural progress takes place by exploring new possibilities that may or may not work.
# Importance of Education and Creativity

Section Overview: No technology can lead to economic gains without a cultural and educational system that encourages creative exploration, independence of thought, willingness to challenge accepted beliefs, and more. The purpose of cultural enrichment and education is not just for economic gain but also for personal growth.
## Education Shaping Towards Passing Examinations
- In recent times, there has been an increasing focus on shaping education towards passing examinations.
- Tests can be useful for both the person taking the test and instructors to understand what needs improvement in the course of instruction.
- However, test results should not be given too much importance as a person can do well on every test but still understand very little.
## Tests as Hurdles

- Tests can be a useful device if they contribute to constructive purposes of education. If they are just hurdles that students have to cross, it can turn out to be meaningless and divert them away from things they want to do.
- Teachers often face situations where students are compelled to pass national exams that determine their future instead of being allowed to explore their interests.
## Pursuing Topics That Engage Us
- Pursuing topics that engage us is far more significant than passing tests.

- Teaching should inspire students to discover on their own, challenge if they don't agree, look for alternatives if they think there are better ones, work through great achievements of the past and try mastering them on their own because they're interested in them.
# Helping Students Learn Independently
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker emphasizes the importance of helping students learn how to learn on their own.
## Learning Independence
- The goal is to help students become independent learners.
- This means not just absorbing information given to them from outside sources and repeating it.
- Students need to be able to think critically and apply what they have learned in new situations.
- Developing these skills will benefit them throughout their lives.

div.h2: "Ignorance is the biggest resistance to Learning"
div.span: Roger makes a critical point here. He points out that a real education of arts and sciences is differential and is radically different than ideological learning. Ideologies are integral and divide, and people who are educated in that way do not have the capacity to hear otherwise. Therefore Ignorance is pervasive not because people are stupid, but because people really don't know.

Detailed Summary for [Karl Popper - Falsificationism, Conjectures & Refutations, Inductive Skepticism](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM) by [Merlin](https://merlin.foyer.work/)
[00:00](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=0) We discuss the philosophy of Karl Popper.
- Karl Popper was a philosopher who lived from 1902 to 1994 and began his career in Vienna.
- He had significant interactions with Sigmund Freud, Alfred Adler, Karl Marx, and Albert Einstein in his youth.
[02:03](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=123) Popper's intellectual development was influenced by Einstein's theories and his criticism of Freud, Adler, and Marx.
- Popper found it difficult to find situations that Freud, Adler, and Marx couldn't explain, while Einstein's theories made bold predictions.
- Popper's most important works include 'The Logic of Scientific Discovery', 'Conjectures and Refutations', 'Objective Knowledge', and 'The Open Society and Its Enemies'.

[04:06](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=246) Popper's philosophy includes anti-totalitarian, anti-utopian, and anti-marxist ideas, and his significant contribution is the demarcation problem.
- Popper's philosophy of science focuses on distinguishing science from non-science.
- He initially characterized this as a question of different types of theories, but later shifted to thinking of it in terms of the practices or attitudes of the scientists in question.
- Popper's focus is different from the logical empiricists who emphasized verificationism.
[06:02](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=362) Popper's falsificationism is the answer to the demarcation problem.
- Popper believes that a theory must be refutable by specific evidence to be scientific.
- Science takes risks by making predictions that could turn out to be false and about novel things.
[07:56](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=476) Pseudoscience is characterized by unfalsifiable claims
- According to Popper, pseudoscience makes empirical claims that are not risky
- Theory can explain away any observation, making it unfalsifiable
[09:51](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=591) Popper's scientific process involves conjecture and refutation.
- The first stage involves creatively proposing theoretical conjectures and constructing theories and hypotheses.
- The second stage involves testing these theories in an attempt to refute them, rather than confirm them.
[11:46](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=706) Popper rejects logical justification for induction
- Popper embraces Hume's conclusion that there is no logical justification for induction
- Popper believes scientific theories can only be refuted, not confirmed
[13:40](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZvFsUE1TM&t=820) Introduction to Karl Popper's philosophy of science
- Popper's philosophy distinguishes between well-confirmed theories and those that aren't
- Popper's account of corroboration is criticized for its effectiveness

div.h2: The U.S. Education System

span.div: # Importance of Public Education

Section Overview: Noam Chomsky discusses the importance of public education and how it contributed to the economic growth of the US after World War II. He also talks about how public education is being systematically destroyed in many states.
## The Role of Public Education in Economic Growth
- The public education system was one of the major achievements of the US and contributed to its economic growth.
- After World War II, the GI Bill allowed a huge number of people to go to college who would never have been able to do so before.
- College was cheap and public education was free during those days.
## Attack on Public Education
- There is an attack on public education which is unprecedented, from kindergarten up to universities.
- In Mexico City, there is a city-run college that is not only free but has open admissions.
- In California, tuition fees are so high that it's only for the rich. For the first time this year, more funding for public institutions comes from tuition than from state funding.
- The great universities in California will almost certainly be privatized as they are almost private now with very high tuitions and big endowments.
## Change in State Capitalism
- There has been a significant change in contemporary state capitalism since the 70s where CEOs no longer care about brand loyalty or building firms that persist.
- Instead, they focus on making money in the short term without regard for long-term consequences such as offshoring production which harms their own country severely.
# Attack on Public Education and Social Security

Section Overview: Noam Chomsky discusses the attack on public education and social security, arguing that it is based on a fundamental principle of caring for others that is considered dangerous by those in power.
## The Attack on Public Education and Social Security
- There is a major effort to destroy the public school system and Social Security.
- The attack on Social Security is partly because it does not benefit the rich, but also because it is based on the principle of caring for others.
- There is a propaganda effort to drive into people's heads that they should only be concerned with themselves, which has been ongoing since at least 1850.
- This effort to turn people into self-centered individuals who care about nothing but themselves is dangerous, especially when it happens in the richest and most powerful country in history.

div.h2: Teaching for a test or educating our students?

div.h2: The mind-bending physics of time

span.p: Sean Carroll explores the concept of time and its properties, as well as the direction of time, in relation to the laws of physics.
He explains that time is a way to differentiate events in the Universe and that it has a direction that we perceive as the past, present, and future.
However, the fundamental laws of physics do not distinguish between the past and the future.
The arrow of time is a result of the low entropy at the beginning of the Universe, known as the Past hypothesis.
Carroll also argues that entropy, the measure of how disorganized a system is, is the key to understanding the arrow of time and the evolution of the Universe.

Without increasing entropy, there would be no interesting things happening, no memory of the past, and no causal effects on the future. Therefore, entropy is necessary for life and interesting phenomena to exist.
Time is a commonly used noun in English. It helps us distinguish between moments, but its properties and direction are confusing.

div.h2: The Ending of Time - Discussion on materialism and conflict
div.span: In summary, the discussion is about the nature of materialism and how it relates to the mind and thought. Materialism is the belief that matter is all there is, and that all reactions and actions in the natural and human world are the result of matter in movement. The speaker suggests that living within this materialistic perspective is shallow and without meaning, and that recognizing thought as a material process is important. They question whether it is possible for the mind to go beyond reaction and whether an empty mind, free from the things that thought has brought about, is a reaction itself. The speaker suggests that by being watchful and attentive to the process of reacting, it can come to an end, and that understanding this is important before discussing what lies beyond it.

div.h2: Anarchism - The Definition with examples

div.span: In this section, the interviewer asks Chomsky about his views on anarchism and what attracts him to it.

span.div: ## Anarchism is not bomb-throwing mayhem
- Chomsky explains that anarchism has nothing to do with 'bomb-throwing mayhem'.
- Anarchism is a point of view which covers a lot of things.
- The mainstream principle of anarchism comes straight out of classical liberalism and the Enlightenment.
- Any form of authority and domination has a burden of proof to bear; it has to demonstrate that it's legitimate.
## Legitimate Authority
- If any form of authority can demonstrate that it's legitimate, then it's okay. Otherwise, it ought to be dismantled.
- It is the task for those who have the authority to demonstrate what is considered 'legitimate authorities'.
- The burden of proof is always on those who exercise authority.
- There's no general definition of what 'legitimate authority' is. It's the task of those who exercise authority to demonstrate their legitimacy.
# Legitimacy and Institutions
Section Overview: In this section, Chomsky talks about how institutions must show their legitimacy in order for them to be considered legitimate.
## Responsibility in Democratic States
- To challenge an institution or person exercising authority, one must meet the challenge.
- In democratic states, interchange among the population recognizes the authority of actions in public arenas through constant interaction, debate, struggle, etc.
## Illegitimacy in Other Systems of Authority
- To the extent that democratic states don't meet the challenge, they are illegitimate.
- In other systems of authority like private corporations or fascist states, there's no question of legitimacy because they have none.
- It is the responsibility of people to make the challenge.

This education is meant to prepare individuals for a stellar civilization, as our species evolves from a single planet-centered species to one that will inhabit the entire star system.

The education pulls together the entire heritage of this particular planet and integrates it in a limited sequence so that an individual can make available at least the introductory interfaces necessary for being a planetary person who is capable of a stellar civilization.

ul.li: 01:11:58 The speaker introduces the concept of Grandfather Phasing as an American Indian wisdom.
01:12:43 He explains that every other phase in the five-phase energy cycle works together, with each phase having a resonant quality with another phase.
01:13:07 The third phase is Gen, which is usually human-heartedness.
01:13:41 The fourth phase is characterized as E or symbols like trigrams or hexagrams of I Ching.
01:14:10 The fifth phase is Li, which represents the world of ten thousand things or multiplicity.
01:14:47 Every other phase has a resonant quality so that if you take Te and Li E, they work together.

01:15:37 Man is not resonant with oneness but with zero and multiplicity.
01:16:36 There's something about our reality and the reality of Tao that form a pair.
01:17:09 Gen in this grandfather phasing way is understood as a Chinese Taoist would understand it.
01:17:36 The symbols of the I Ching are derived from Tay and not from Tao or man.
01:18:15 The expressive symbol of Tai Chi is in the fourth phase, but its actual efficacy is not in any kind of symbol but in its operative manifestation.

ul.li: 16:56 Siddhartha realized that the stuck voice existed in a realm not amenable to the four yogas of this world.
He had run through the complete cycle of teachers, but none of them could provide a solution.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 17:25 Siddhartha decided to force himself into enlightenment by taking no more nourishment whatsoever.
He reached a condition where he was only bones and skin and fell on his face in the dust.
An old woman mixed a little bit of rice with her saliva and forced it into his mouth, bringing him back to some low modicum of life over several weeks.
Coming out of his own giving up, Siddhartha began to understand that there was no power in him for enlightenment.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 18:43 Enlightenment cannot be achieved or found; it cannot be forced as there is nothing one can do.
The mind has no way of interfacing with it, and it doesn't have existence.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

When he had gained whatever was there to be gained, he would go home.

ul.li: 19:39 Siddhartha positioned himself in the forest and sat under a tree.
He sat under the first tree, a mucha Linda tree, for seven days.
As he sat there, the realization that he would never achieve enlightenment ebbed from him.
He then sat under a second tree for another seven days and a third tree for a third seven days.

ul.li: 21:46 Siddhartha sat under the fourth tree, which was a ficus tree known as the Bodhi Tree.
For a cycle of seven days or one week, nothing happened whatsoever.

It occurred to Siddhartha that he had no hands with which to accept this bowl of food and that he had nothing whatsoever to say.

ul.li: 29:14 Maha Kasiapa was the greatest black magic practitioner in Ancient India with an army of super snake yogis.
29:52 When Buddha was about 60 or 70 years old, he walked into Kasiapa's camp alone and unarmed.
30:24 Buddha asked if he could spend the night in Kasiapa's hut, which had a lot of weird energy related to snakes.
30:50 Buddha went into deep samadhi and conjured up all the snakes that Kundalini is capable of, but they couldn't find any spinal column to wrap themselves around.
31:57 Over the years, Kasiapa became Mahakashyapa, one of the greatest followers of Buddha.

ul.li: The Dhammapada begins with a section called the Twin Verses or Yamakavagam.
This section consists of ten pairs of verses arranged in equanimity, meant to bring one's language capacity to symbolic honing.
Tuning up ten times in this way prepares one to hear the rest of the verses in a kind of linearity.

ul.li: After tuning up, one must remind oneself to be heedful.
Heedfulness is about melting a snowflake of process that needs to melt all at once.
There are six parameters or perfections that make up the jewel of heedfulness.

span.p: Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses a phrase from the beginning of the Dhammapada: "Our life is the creation of our mind." The speaker explains how this phrase relates to worldly truth and fifth yoga.

ul.li: The phrase "Our life is the creation of our mind" is true in this world but its truth vanishes in fifth yoga and reappears mysteriously.
Because it was both true and not true then it becomes real.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: To become a pedestrian on the Dharma Pata, one has to walk in fifth yoga.
The four natural yogas hone you so you can follow a linear path but only someone who can transcend can follow Paryana (the path).
If you cannot hear the Dhammapada in a linear way, then you have to do some serious practice with some of the basic yogas because you're missing out on even being able to follow linearity.

ul.li: 11:34 The difference between art and ritual is that art participates in an entirely different mode of happening from ritual.
Ritual guarantees that you do this same action over and over again.
Arts guarantee exactly the opposite: that you don't do the same thing over and over again but you do something new.

22:23 This ritual ensured that the new prince was seen as a legitimate king, making it an archetypal myth at the center of the Roman Empire.
22:43 Fraser wanted to understand why such a peculiar myth was so important to such a practical concern as the Roman Empire.

26:14 During World War I, he discovered that natives understood their lives well and were professional about how they lived.
27:03 Malinowski wrote Coral Gardens and Their Magic, which explained how natives ensured their food supply was guaranteed by using talismanic spells and formulas to keep their food pure.
27:28 The exchange of shared food was a reciprocity in action that served as the glue for society.

div.h2: Noam Chomsky - Do the Powerful Know What's Going On?
div.span: Noam Chomsky says that the way to make change is to work with the powerless and masses. The powerful know the problems and will not work against their own interest, by informing the masses we can make change.

div.h2: Vijay Prashad: History Is A Series Of Experiments
div.span: In this conversation, Vijay Prashad discusses the human desire to find meaning in history and to understand the purpose of events. He compares the ways in which different cultures throughout history have sought purpose in their own time periods, including through religious sacrifices and philosophical examination. Prashad also touches on the idea that history can be seen as a series of experiments, with different societies and movements attempting different ways of organizing and governing themselves in order to create a better world.

div.h2: Why are National Infrastructure Banks Necessary?
div.span: A national infrastructure bank is a bank established by a government to fund and make loans to companies that are improving or creating new infrastructure. These projects, such as roads or bridges, are socially valuable but may not be pursued by private companies because they may not generate enough profit for the company. The national infrastructure bank is able to fund these projects by offering low interest loans to companies, making it worthwhile for them to pursue the project despite the lower profit margin. This helps to ensure that socially valuable infrastructure projects are completed, even if they may not be as profitable as other projects that private companies could pursue.

div.h2: Ending disorder is the ending of death
div.span: Conversation between J. Krishnamurti and Father Eugene Schallert. The conversation centers around the concept of perception and how it is influenced by biases and prejudices. Krishnamurti argues that these biases prevent true perception and lead to escape through ideologies and concepts. Father Schallert asks about the role of oneness or truth in perception, and Krishnamurti responds that they should focus on the shared human experience of confusion, battle, misery, and loneliness. The conversation also touches on the importance of attention and the role of the ego in preventing true perception.

div.h2: Goodness only flowers in freedom
div.span: Dialogue between two people, J. Krishnamurti and Father Eugene Schallert, on the topic of freedom and perception. They discuss the role of culture and religion in shaping the mind and how these factors can limit one's freedom. They also mention the importance of seeing things clearly and breaking through conditioning to reach a state of ultimate freedom. The conversation touches on various issues such as politics, religion, culture, and the nature of reality.

div.h2: What is thought?
div.span: Thinking is the process by which the brain uses memory, knowledge, and experience to analyze and understand information, solve problems, and make decisions. It is a fundamental part of the human experience and is present in all aspects of life, from driving a car to building cathedrals to relationships with others. Krishnamurti suggests that thought is rooted in fear and is limited by memory and experience, which can lead to conflict. He encourages the viewer to investigate thinking and its origins in order to potentially bring about a "mutation" or change in the way we think.

div.h2: What is guilt?
div.span: In this talk, Krishnamurti is exploring the concept of guilt and the ways in which it affects people's lives. He suggests that guilt can be a very distorting and destructive force, and that it is important to understand how to deal with it effectively. Krishnamurti asks his audience to consider how they approach problems, and whether they always approach them with a motive or desire to resolve them. He suggests that it might be possible to approach problems without any preconceived notions or background knowledge, and to look at them as if for the first time. Krishnamurti also discusses the idea that guilt can be caused by a lack of responsibility or a sense of not being true to oneself. He encourages his audience to consider how they can approach guilt in a way that allows them to be free of it, and to be more fully present in their lives.

div.h2: Vijay Prashad on Ho Chi Minh
div.span: Ho Chi Minh was a Vietnamese communist revolutionary leader who was the prime minister and president of Vietnam. He was born into a Confucian patriotic family in central Vietnam and was sent to study in the French education system in Vietnam. While in France, he was disappointed by the failure of French republicanism and the brutality of French colonialism in Vietnam. He became interested in communism after meeting Communists in France and was particularly drawn to the ideas of Lenin, who argued in favor of the right of colonies to independence. Ho Chi Minh went to Moscow, where he became a teacher at the School of the Toilers of the East and was trained in Marxist ideas and communist practice. He dedicated his life to liberating Vietnam and establishing a socialist government there.

div.h2: Noam Chomsky: A Critique of Democracy (1997)
div.span: Mr. Chomsky examined the principle and practice of democracy in the U.S. over the past 200 years. He also argued that this system has not evolved to include broader segments of the population, as some have claimed, but has made possible the development of industrial capitalism which depends on governmental largesse and exploits the bulk of the population. After his remarks, he took questions from the audience.

span.p: Chris and Prashad talk about activism and how it is possible to make a difference. They talk about how our current system has demobilized us and turned us into consumers. He talks about the adverse effects of the new amazon capitalism that disconnects us from our community.

div.h2: Jewish Business Ethics
div.span: This is a great insight into how religion works. The idea is that there is a book that contains all the information we ever need, and we need to follow those guideline to belong! This is the mentality and teachings of all religions. In the 21st century we need a different education!

div.h2: Noam Chomsky on Religion and morality
div.span: Chomsky says he believes in a principle that was enunciated by Bertrand Russell that one should not believe in irrational thoughts. Learn what it means to be committed to the scientific methods.

div.h2: Dave Chappelle Stand-Up Monologue - SNL
div.span: Dave Chappelle talks about Kanye West, the 2022 midterm elections and Donald Trump. This is a 15 minute monologue and its a master piece.

div.h2: The ROOT CAUSE Of Trauma & Why You FEEL LOST In Life
div.span: Dr. Maté generously shares his deep understanding of childhood trauma, vulnerability, grief, and emotional distress. He explains what real trauma is and how time doesn’t necessarily lead to healing, how vulnerability is ingrained in us since we are young and the importance of these formative years to mold our emotional health, and the societal expectations we always try to meet but have never truly given us real fulfillment.

div.h2: Noam Chomsky on Legacy of Radical Historian Staughton Lynd, Who Protested Korea, Vietnam & Iraq Wars
div.span: Noam Chomsky remembers the life and legacy of longtime peace and civil rights activist, lawyer and author Staughton Lynd, who has died at the age of 92. Lynd faced professional blowback after he was a conscientious objector during the Korean War and an outspoken critic of the Vietnam War, and later supported U.S. soldiers who refused to fight in Iraq.

div.h2: Steve Jobs MIT 1992 - Operational Productivity
div.span: Great language about productivity that I can apply to Kurator and knowledge management. Talks about demand for front part of the corporations to design applications.

div.h2: Noam Chomsky on Libertarian Socialism
div.span: Chomsky on libertarian socialism, anarchism and anarcho-syndicalism. Chomsky reveals the real meaning of Libertarian as understood and practiced by the Europeans versus the American version of this term.

div.h2: Krishnamurti, chronicles of a less ordinary life.
div.span: An introduction and invitation to meet the great and radical philosopher J. Krishnamurti. He is seen here through the eyes of two of his close friends : Radhika Herzberger and Samdhong Rinpoche. Krishnamurti was one of the greatest thinkers of the 20th century and this film could perhaps awaken the curiosity of a new cotemporary audience. Apart from his talks and public lecture, Krishnamurti instigated schools in India, England and America. This schools continue to this day.

ul.li: 07:44 The modern cognitive sciences can be traced back to a meeting in 1956 held in Cambridge, where research papers were presented that initiated the modern field.

08:01 The confluence of research papers outlined basic ideas of generative grammar, problem-solving, reasoning, and experimental human psychology which made use of information theory and signal detection.
08:31 A shift occurred from studying behavior and its products towards studying states, properties, and processes of the mind that enter into human thought and action.

ul.li: 11:46 There was an interest in computational representational systems as a way to look at mental activities and faculties as a kind of software problem.

12:10 These theories attempt to establish states and properties that have to be accommodated somehow in brain sciences. They might provide guidelines for inquiry into mechanisms or radical changes in how we conceive the brain's processes.

ul.li: 19:29 Unlike visual perception, we know a lot about the generative procedures involved in language.
19:50 One major assumption is that there is something called a parser which maps a signal into a symbolic representation paying no attention to any other aspects of the relevant environment.
20:16 It's assumed that people use their knowledge of English when interpreting signals.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 20:37 The existence of an internal generative procedure is far more secure and obvious than the existence of a parser.
21:00 Parsing often fails completely and quite systematically, and it's often extremely difficult.
21:22 There is only indirect evidence for the assumption that parsing doesn't grow from some initial state to a stable state.
21:41 A forthcoming book by Robert Berwick and Sandui Fong suggests that there may be a universal parser which has fixed invariant properties for different languages.
22:28 The design of language appears to make it largely unusable, but we just use those fragments that are usable for us.

ul.li: 36:23 Scientists and philosophers were fascinated by automata that simulated natural processes.
Their goal was to learn about the natural process itself rather than answering questions about whether machines can truly replicate them.

span.p: Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses unification among various branches of cognitive sciences. He argues that while there is some commonality among physical organs below the neck, it is not clear if there is any other level at which these systems are unified.

ul.li: 37:08 Physical organs below the neck (e.g., circulatory system, digestive system, visual system) fall together at some level (presumably at cellular biology).
Studying these abstract organs does fall together at some level.

ul.li: 37:52 The brain appears to be an extremely intricate system with all kinds of subparts that have special design.
It's not clear if mental organs are unified in some kind of mental organ theory above the level of cellular biology.
If there is no intermediate level for unification, then there is no cognitive science.

span.p: Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses two approaches to the question of unification: modular and uniform. He argues that evidence is overwhelmingly in favor of highly modular approaches.

ul.li: 39:10 One approach assumes modularity, meaning mental organs have special design.
The other approach assumes uniformity, meaning there are general mechanisms of learning or thinking which are just applied to different domains.

ul.li: 40:36 Evidence is overwhelmingly in favor of highly modular approaches.
Even internally within the language faculty, there seems to be quite highly modular design.
Capacities such as grammatical ability, conceptual ability, and pragmatic ability have been discovered to be dissociated developmentally and selectively impaired under injury.

span.p: Section Overview: This section discusses the modularity of language and how it is not linked to particular processing systems. It also explores the study of sign language and its surprising similarities to spoken language acquisition.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 42:17 Sign language is localized in speech areas of the brain in the left hemisphere, not in visual processing areas.
42:39 Children acquiring sign language go through stages similar to spoken language acquisition, even overriding obvious iconic properties of visual symbols.
43:19 There is a case on record of spontaneous invention of sign language by three deaf children who had no environmental model or stimulus.
43:40 The system constructed by these children has standard properties of natural spoken language.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 44:03 The language faculty grows a language much like other organs grow, largely determined by its inner nature.
44:25 The developmental stages appear to be similar across sensory modalities.
44:45 The cognitive revolution rediscovered long-forgotten ideas from the first cognitive revolution in psychology and physiology during the 17th and 18th centuries.
45:31 Traditional themes could be productively engaged with formal sciences providing enough understanding.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 45:52 Human language is a process that makes infinite use of finite means.
46:37 Formal sciences have provided enough understanding for many traditional themes to be productively engaged.

span.h1: 47:35 The Concept of Exterior and Interior

span.p: Section Overview: In this section, Noam Chomsky discusses the concept of exterior and interior in relation to objects like houses and airplanes.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: Objects like houses and airplanes have an exterior surface that can be seen from the outside.
However, they also have a distinguished interior that cannot be seen from the outside.
The nature of the interior does not seem to matter much as it is a special combination of abstract yet concrete interior with an abstract exterior.

span.p: Section Overview: In this section, Noam Chomsky talks about container words like "house" and their properties.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: Container words like "house" have extremely weird properties that cannot be found in any object in the world.
These properties are unlearned but universal, meaning they are part of our nature.
Language acquisition is more like biological growth where we fill in details into a predetermined structure that goes back to our nature.

ul.li: Eliminating a phrase from a sentence changes its interpretation to mean "something or other."
For example, "John ate an apple" becomes "John ate something or other."
Similarly, dropping the last phrase in a sentence changes its interpretation to mean "so much so that..."
For example, "John is too stubborn to talk to Bill" becomes "John is so stubborn he won't talk to Bill."

span.p: Section Overview: In this section, Noam Chomsky discusses language acquisition and how it is a part of our nature. He explains that there are generative procedures in the brain that grow in the language faculty virtually without experience.

ul.li: 53:01 Language acquisition is a part of our nature.
53:44 None of the intricacies of language are mentioned or hinted at in grammar books.
54:04 There is a huge variety of material that has come to light as a direct consequence of discovering and formulating generative procedures that grow in the language faculty.
55:00 There are extremely intricate things known even in the simplest cases, which cannot be picked up from experience and consequently they're universal.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 55:23 A lexicon is a selection of concepts associated with particular sounds.
55:45 The association between a concept and sound looks free, but determining which concepts are associated with which sounds is trivial.
56:06 The lexicon also contains formal elements like inflections such as tense or plural markers found in languages like German or Latin.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 56:46 Languages appear to differ substantially in their formal elements, but this seems mostly illusory.
57:20 Some aspects of the computational system receive external articulation while others do not.

ul.li: 58:15 It's possible that there is only one unique human language.
58:37 Acquisition of language would be a miracle if there were many languages, but if there is only one, it becomes more plausible.
58:55 Each possible language may be fixed by answering a finite number of simple questions.
59:17 Children can learn languages highly efficiently and very fast with very little evidence.
59:35 Languages appear to be learnable which is surprising but they also appear to be unusable.

ul.li: 01:03:51 Certain computations in language converge to yield interpretable instructions.
If either the phonetic instructions or the articulatory perceptual system fails, we say that it doesn't converge.
Some convergent computations are blocked by more economical derivations.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 01:04:13 A linguistic expression is nothing other than the optimal realization of certain external interface conditions.
A language is a setting of certain switches and an expression of the language is the optimal realization of universal interface conditions.
All work is done by special properties of computation and notions of economy.

h2.style: box-sizing: border-box; line-height: 1.35; flex-shrink: 0; width: 597.664px; max-width: 100%; padding-right: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); padding-left: calc(var(--bs-gutter-x)*0.5); margin-top: 1em !important; margin-bottom: 0.5em !important;

ul.li: 01:05:15 Economy conditions have a global character to them but tend to yield high degrees of computational complexity that would render large parts of language unusable.
Parts that are rendered unusable due to computational complexity are not necessarily an empirical objection.
Languages may be learnable because there isn't much to learn, but they're surprisingly beautiful.

Introspection suggests that expressing thoughts through language happens all the time.

ul.li: 01:09:27Language acquisition is not possible without linguistic expression.
01:09:44It would be interesting to figure out a way to articulate non-linguistic thoughts.

ul.li: 01:10:01Writing is an input system, but whether it's a natural system is unclear.
01:10:23Children cannot learn language from writing; they can only learn it from sign or hearing.

- Transitional probabilities between sounds predict word boundaries.
- Probabilities drop sharply at word boundaries, but are high within words.
[03:05] Method of applying constraints to language analysis improves results
- Applying a constraint of pitch stress peaks in words results in better analysis
- Further improvement can be obtained by using prosodic phrases
[04:10] Transitional probabilities can identify word boundaries in language
- This method was studied seriously by a former student, Lisa Selkirk
- Sophisticated statistical analysis without concern for language structure achieves odd success
[05:13] Interpreting success in science as approximating unanalyzed data
- Studying communication through extensive videotaping and statistical analysis could yield better predictions
- Further testing through more videotaping and statistics could be applied to physics
[06:10] Analysis of nature's behavior can predict future outcomes
- Observation and analysis can lead to successful predictions in the behavior of nature
- Success is measured differently in this field and should not be compared to traditional scientific success
[07:01] No successful cases exist where unanalyzed data is used without approximations
- Approximations are needed to analyze unanalyzed data
- Successful cases integrate language properties

div.h2: Debunking the great AI lie

div.span: The speaker introduces Noam Chomsky and Gary Marcus for a discussion on the myths surrounding artificial intelligence.

span.div: ## Introducing Noam Chomsky and Gary Marcus

- Noam Chomsky, the father of modern Linguistics, joins scientist author and entrepreneur Gary Marcus for a wide-ranging discussion on why the myths surrounding artificial intelligence are so dangerous.
- They will discuss why we should not rely on AI to save us all.
# [00:57] Disappointments with AI Technology
Noam Chomsky discusses his disappointment with current AI technology.
## Deficiencies in GPT System
- GPT system is deficient in certain areas.
- It does not do certain things that other systems can do.
- It is too strong and does what it shouldn't do.
- There are lots of ways in which the system is deficient.
- The problem with GPT and other systems is that they work just as well for impossible languages as for possible ones by definition not telling us anything about language.
## Problems with Deep Learning Systems
- Deep learning systems have two problems: being too weak or too strong.
- When a system is too strong, it's unfixable typically, and that's the problem with GPT and other systems.
# [02:34] Modes of Failure in AI Systems
Gary Marcus talks about modes of failure in AI systems.
## Examples of Problems with Dolly System
- Dolly system has problems putting together meanings from the orders of words.
- If you tell it to draw a blue cube on top of a Red Cube, it might just give you a Red Cube on top of a blue cube.
# [06:49] The Limitations of AI Systems
In this section, the speakers discuss the limitations of current AI systems and their inability to understand language and objects.
## Understanding Language and Objects
- [07:06] Current AI systems lack an understanding of language and objects.
- [07:25] These systems fail to understand concepts such as theory of mind or implications in language.
- [07:42] Despite being able to draw pictures, these systems have a shallow understanding of language and cannot explain why human language is unique.
## Engineering vs Science
- [08:38] Engineering achievements are different from scientific ones.
- [09:08] While engineering can produce useful results, science aims to understand the world.
- [09:34] Deep learning approaches have produced helpful results with regard to protein folding but do not contribute much scientifically.
## Dangers of Overestimating Capabilities
- [11:50] There is a danger in overestimating the capabilities of current AI systems.
- These tools may be useful but they are not capable of true artificial general intelligence.
# [12:34] Introduction
In this section, the speaker discusses how the popularity of large language models like GPT-3 is taking away energy from cognitive science and perpetuating past biases.
## Large Language Models
- [12:34] At a local maximum, we have something that looks good but isn't really as deep as we need it and it's sucking the oxygen away from the field of cognitive science.
- [12:50] Young graduate students are more likely to work on GPT-3 than in Linguistics because they get paid more. This is short-sighted since GPT-3 has a short road ahead.
- [13:05] The history of AI shows that there have been fads over and over again, such as expert systems and support vector machines. We need something more stable.
## Perpetuation of Past Biases
- [13:21] Large language models perpetuate past data, which means they're sexist and racist even though they're not built to be that way.
- [13:54] These systems produce misinformation at scale, which can be devastating to the democratic process.
# [14:09] Dangers of Large Language Models
In this section, the speaker discusses specific dangers associated with large language models like GPT-3.
## Misinformation

- [14:09] The amount of misinformation troll farms will be able to produce using custom versions of GPT-3 for less than half a million dollars will completely change the world in the next couple of years.
## Threat to Democracy
- [14:24] A system that can make sentences that are grammatical but make up stuff like "why is it good to eat socks after meditating" can lead people to believe false information.
- [14:41] The threat to democracy is more concerning than investors wasting their money.
## Modes of Failure
- [14:58] There's a danger in believing the hype and thinking these systems are more capable than they actually are.

- [15:26] The speaker predicts that 2023 will be the first year in which there's a death attributable to one of these systems either because it tells somebody to commit suicide or somebody falls in love with one of these systems but the system doesn't actually love them back and they've added it or because it tells them to mix Clorox with Drano and they drink it all.
# [16:00] Understanding Large Language Models
In this section, the speaker discusses how large language models like GPT-3 work and their contribution to linguistics.
## Autocomplete on Steroids

- [16:00] GPT-3 is really just autocomplete on steroids. It gives an illusion that it's more than that, but what they're really doing is basically a version of autocomplete like in your phone you predict the next word.
## Contribution to Linguistics
- No content available.
# [16:56] Behavioral and Computer Science

The speaker discusses a study that was published in a journal which had all of Reddit and other things in its database. The study aimed to understand the frequency of words used and how it can help with language understanding.
## Purpose of AI
- [18:41] The original goal of AI was to use the capacities developed in computer science to understand something about how humans think.
- [19:55] Early pioneers in the field, such as Simon Marvinsky, were interested in learning something about cognition thinking.
- [20:29] However, this has been replaced over the years by playing with fancy computers and programming systems.
## Current State of AI
- [17:51] Snowplows are not making any contribution to science or helping us understand the world.
- [20:35] Current enthusiasm for deep learning is ignoring many things we know about cognitive science.
- [22:42] People building language production systems should learn about syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.
## Conclusion
- There has been no real contribution towards understanding the nature of language or any other cognitive process through current AI practices.
# [23:19] Introduction to GPT and its limitations
In this section, the speaker introduces GPT and discusses its limitations.
## GPT's Limitations
- [23:19] GPT is powerful but may not always produce what you want.

- [23:36] Google's paper on Palm seiken shows that GPT3 works three-quarters of the time in a robot, but one-quarter of the time it doesn't work. This can be dangerous if used for tasks like putting someone to bed.
- [24:10] Cognitive science tells us that we need to map meaning onto sentences or vice versa, even with all the data available.

- [24:42] Using neural networks without knowledge-based approaches can lead to incorrect answers based on statistical mimicry. For example, asking who the president of the United States is might result in an answer of Donald Trump because there are more examples of him than Joe Biden in some datasets.
# [25:12] Cognitive Science and AI
In this section, the speaker discusses how cognitive science can inform AI development.
## Cognitive Science Principles
- [25:12] Cognitive scientists think about things like discourse models and how we talk about things.
- [25:27] Innateness is a foundational principle in cognitive science. When learning language, we don't start from a blank slate; rather, we have innate knowledge built into our minds.

- [25:43] The empiricist hypothesis that cognition will emerge if given enough data has been shown to be false by developmental psychologists. Children seem to have an innate sense of how objects exist in the world.
# [26:00] Failure of Empiricist Hypothesis
In this section, the speaker discusses how the failure of the empiricist hypothesis affects AI development.
## Failure of Empiricist Hypothesis
- [26:00] The idea that the right things will emerge if given enough data is like magic and has been shown to be false.
- [26:16] A benchmark based on what 10-month-olds do in the lab shows that current AI systems don't understand basic physics concepts like objects dropping or being hidden.

- [26:33] Developmental psychologists have shown that children likely have innate knowledge about how objects exist in the world. Starting with a blank slate and accumulating statistics doesn't lead to true understanding.
# [27:38] The Future of AI

In this section, the speakers discuss the need for a synthesis between neural networks and symbolic AI. They also emphasize the importance of having a large database of machine-interpretable knowledge.
## Combining Neural Networks and Symbolic AI
- [27:38] Neural networks are good at learning from data but not very good at abstract knowledge.
- [27:56] Symbolic AI is good with abstract knowledge but not learning from data.
- [27:38] A synthesis between the two is necessary to achieve general intelligence.
## Importance of Machine-Interpretable Knowledge
- [27:56] Current AI systems lack rich and abstract knowledge.
- [28:10] Abstract knowledge is crucial for reasoning about things, making inferences, and having cognitive models of the world.
- [28:26] Foundational ideas in cognitive science involve maintaining an internal representation of things in the world, which current AI systems do not represent.
# [28:59] Incorporating Innateness into AI Systems
In this section, the speakers discuss incorporating innate properties into AI systems. They also mention how early AI was not distinct from cognitive science.
## Innate Properties in Cognitive Science
- [28:59] Acquiring cognitive capacities involves fundamental built-in innate properties.
- [29:30] Understanding these innate properties should be taken into account when developing AI systems.
## Early Days of AI and Cognitive Science
- [29:58] Early days of AI were not distinct from cognitive science.
- [30:20] Using achievements in intellectual and technological advancements was a way to advance cognitive science.
# [31:09] Understanding Language Acquisition in Children
In this section, the speakers discuss language acquisition in children and how it can be used to inform AI systems.
## Innate Basis for Language Acquisition
- [31:09] Children acquire language on the basis of innate properties triggered by stimulation.
- [31:40] Incorporating this understanding into AI methods could lead to advancements in cognitive science.
# Conclusion

The speakers emphasize the need for a synthesis between neural networks and symbolic AI, as well as the importance of incorporating innate properties into AI systems. They also mention how early AI was not distinct from cognitive science and how understanding language acquisition in children can inform AI systems.
