- [07:40](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=460) Establish a technology control regime to block China's strategic capabilities.

- [08:09](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=489) Build up power political capacities of US friends and allies on China's periphery and strengthen US military forces along the Asian rimland despite any Chinese opposition.
# [08:36](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=516) Multi-Polarity in World Affairs

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about how most of the world wants a multi-polar world and does not want the US as the global preeminent power. He also discusses how underlying economics and technological change have made it so that we are in fact in a multi-polar world.
## Most of the World Wants Multi-Polarity
- [08:36](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=516) Most of the world wants a multi-polar world.
- [09:06](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=546) This was also President Lula's message when he visited China - Brazil wants true multi-polarity.
## Underlying Economics Have Made It So We Are in Fact in a Multi-Polar World
- [09:34](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=574) The US is no longer the dominant world economy.
- [10:03](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=603) The G7 is smaller than the BRICS countries in economic size.
- [10:29](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=629) The US is withdrawing from the world financial and monetary scene, opening up space for a completely different kind of international finance.
# [10:54](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=654) Changing Scene in International Finance
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about how China and other BRICS countries are creating their own development bank and changing the scene in international finance.
## Creation of Alternative Major Currencies
- [10:54](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=654) The creation of alternative major currencies to the dollar as a result of the BRICS alliance could have an impact on world affairs.
## Changing Scene in International Finance
- [11:15](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=675) The US Congress won't put new money into the World Bank, so China and other BRICS countries created their own Development Bank.
- [11:35](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=695) There's also the Asia Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), based in Beijing.
# [12:25](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=745) Trading in National Currencies

Section Overview: The United States is doubling down on its rule-based international order, but other countries are setting up alternative institutions to trade in their own national currencies. The issue of how much longer the permanent members of the UN Security Council can keep the number to five has been raised by Brazil and other countries of the global South.
## Rule-Based International Order
- Other countries are quickly setting up alternative institutions to trade in their own national currencies. [12:25](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=745)
- The United States government uses the expression "rule-based international order" every day, but what does it mean? [12:46](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=766)
- Most of the world wants rules written in a multi-polar or multilateral setting, not rules written by the United States and a few friends and allies. [13:12](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=792)
## UN Security Council Reform

- Brazil and other countries of the global South have been saying that the UN needs to be reformed and countries from Latin America specifically Brazil and Africa should have representation on the UN Security Council permanent members. [13:41](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=821)

- The P5 (the permanent five which is the United States, China, Russia, France, and the United Kingdom) gave itself power that other 188 countries look on with frustration. India is now the most populous country in the world but not on the security council despite being a nuclear power and world superpower.[14:05](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=845)

- This has been an issue for more than 20 years as various ways have blocked particular countries but added up; P5 has said this is our club we want to stay as permanent five.[15:33](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=933)
# [16:24](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=984) Renovating International Institutions

Section Overview: The international institutions will need to change or they won't function in the 21st century. China is negotiating various agreements, including the peace plan it has put forward and other deals that China is helping to negotiate like the successful rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran.
## Post-Western Dominated World
- We are post-western as well as post-US dominance, and these international institutions will need to change or they won't function in the 21st century.[15:59](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=959)

- If they don't function, it's actually a disaster for us if they didn't exist we'd have to make them because we need them to function so we also need to renovate them.[16:24](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=984)
## China's Role in Negotiations

- Brazil's president Luis enacio Lula de Silva criticized Russia's invasion of Ukraine and suggested that Ukraine is on the verge of a major counter-offensive against Russia. In order to do this, it needs massive support from Western countries meaning military weapons. [17:18](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1038)

- China is negotiating various agreements, including the peace plan it has put forward and other deals that China is helping to negotiate like the successful rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran. [18:09](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1089)
# [19:05](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1145) President Lula and China's Peace Plan

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how President Lula of Brazil and China's peace plan aim to maintain peace by respecting the security interests of all parties involved. They believe that NATO expansion up to Russia's border is a fundamental national security threat.
## The Red Line
- [19:05](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1145) The "red line" has been a clear stance for decades, as stated in 2007 before George W Bush Jr announced Ukraine would be a member of NATO.

- [19:33](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1173) China believes that having a war between Russia and the US over the expansion of the US military alliance right up to Russia's border is essentially a proxy war.

- [20:02](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1202) President Lula and China want peace but not NATO expansion right up to the border. They want big superpowers to give each other some space and distance so that the world isn't on edge.
## Lack of Explanation
- [20:28](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1228) The American people have not heard an explanation about this issue despite it being a major failing. Newspapers won't even report on its background.

- [20:54](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1254) Countries such as China, South Africa, India, Brazil, Saudi Arabia, Iran are saying they want peace but not NATO expansion as part of their so-called peace initiative.
## Negotiating Table
- [21:19](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1279) The reason why we have not been able to get to the negotiating table is because Biden Administration refuses even to discuss this issue.

- [21:43](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1303) Even when Zelensky said in March 2022 maybe not NATO maybe something else Russia and Ukraine were close to an agreement but then the United States intervened with Ukraine.
# [22:03](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1323) True Multi-polarity
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how true multi-polarity is needed to ensure that the US respects some limits based on what other countries say.
## What's at Stake

- [22:03](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1323) From China or Russia's point of view, what is at stake in Ukraine and over Taiwan and many other issues is whether the US does what it wants to do or whether it respects some limits based on what other countries say.
- [22:31](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1351) We need true multi-polarity, not just U.S dominance alone rules written by all of us.
## Parallels with Monroe Doctrine

- [22:57](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1377) This year marks the 200th anniversary of President Monroe declaring to all European powers that the Western Hemisphere was off-limits to them. For these past 200 years, Latin America has been a major sphere of influence for the United States.

- [23:18](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1398) The speaker believes that there are parallels between this expansion of NATO further east in Europe and Russia's right to declare that its immediate bordering countries cannot welcome in NATO troops.
## Empathy
- [23:43](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1423) The United States government refuses empathy because it refuses to put itself in the position of the other side.
- [24:04](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1444) The fundamental arrogance of thinking that you determine the rules of the world is a problem with arrogance.
# [25:07](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1507) The Need for a New U.S. Foreign Policy

## The Importance of Sustainable Development
- [25:07](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1507)Sustainable development is essential to address global challenges such as climate change and poverty.
- [25:15](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1515)The United States needs to prioritize sustainable development in its foreign policy.

- [25:50](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1550)The U.S. should also prioritize diplomacy with China and Russia.
## Addressing Global Challenges
- [26:03](https://youtu.be/rgMPIhBLp1I?t=1563)Global challenges such as climate change require international cooperation.

div.h2: Chris Hedges 'America: The Farewell Tour'

div.span: The introduction provides a brief background of Chris Hedges, his experience as a journalist and author, and his latest book.

span.div: - Chris Hedges is a Pulitzer prize-winning journalist for the New York Times with 15 years of experience as a foreign correspondent.
- He has worked for various media outlets including the Dallas Morning News, the Christian Science Monitor, and NPR.
- Hedges is an ordained Presbyterian minister and a plaintiff in hedges v Obama lawsuit challenging the National Defense Authorization Act of 2012.
- He has authored several award-winning works including "War Is a Force That Gives Us Meaning" and "America: The Farewell Tour."
# About Chris Hedges
Section Overview: This section provides more information about Chris Hedges' career as a journalist.
- Chris Hedges writes a weekly column for TruthDig, an online magazine.
- He is also an Emmy-nominated host of "On Contact," which appears on RT America.
# Books by Chris Hedges
Section Overview: This section lists some of the books written by Chris Hedges.
- War Is a Force That Gives Us Meaning (2002)
- American Fascists (2007)
- I Don't Believe in Atheists (2008)
- Empire of Illusion (2009)
- Days of Destruction, Days of Revolt (2012), co-written with Joe Sacco
- Unspeakable (2016)
- America: The Farewell Tour (latest book)
# Introduction to Talk
Section Overview: This section introduces the topic that will be discussed in the talk.
- The talk will focus on Chris Hedge's latest book, "America: The Farewell Tour."
# Start of Talk
Section Overview: This section marks the beginning of Chris Hedge's talk.
# Recent News Events
Section Overview: This section discusses two recent news events that Chris Hedges finds deeply disturbing.
- Jamal Khashoggi, a columnist for The Washington Post and a friend of Chris Hedges, was apparently murdered in the Saudi consulate in Turkey.
- A Bulgarian investigative journalist was raped and murdered in a park.
- Chris Hedges is disturbed by the fact that the US government will likely not protest or sanction the Saudi regime.
- He supports boycott, divestment, and sanction movements for both Israel and Saudi Arabia.
# Kavanaugh Hearings
Section Overview: This section discusses the Kavanaugh hearings and their implications.
- The Democratic charade has replaced our democratic process.
- Corporate totalitarianism is taking over, and no one seems willing or able to stop it.
# The Link Between Social Bonds and Suicide

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how strong social bonds and individual self-expression can protect against suicide. He also explains how communities with destroyed social bonds are more likely to experience collective or individual suicide.
## Importance of Strong Social Bonds
- Communities with strong social bonds are less likely to engage in acts of self-destruction.
- Strong social bonds provide space for individual self-expression and self-actualization, which is the greatest protection against collective or individual suicide.
## Effects of Destroyed Social Bonds
- Individuals who carry out acts of self-destruction often come from communities where social bonds have been destroyed.

- Anomie, meaning rulelessness, occurs when the accepted rules of the social contract no longer function. This leads to a state of enemy that propels people to engage in activities of self-immolation.
- When contracts between individuals and society are broken, individuals are thrust into a state of enemy or what sociologists call diseases of despair.
# Pathologies That Arise From A Decayed Culture

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker examines pathologies that afflict American society as a result of a decayed culture. He draws parallels between these pathologies and those seen in disintegrating cultures throughout history.
## Characteristics Of Disintegrating Cultures
- Pathologies that arise from a decayed culture are always characteristics.
- The decline of ancient Greece and Rome's empires had characteristics intimately familiar to us within the American Empire.
- Greeks have a different notion of time than Western cultures; they see time as cyclical rather than linear.
- Plato wrote the Republic after the death of Athenian democracy, lamenting the freezing of time to stave off decay.
## Rise Of Empire And Oligarchic Class
- The rise of the Athenian Empire weakened the polis and gave rise to an oligarchic class that eventually took control.
- The tyranny that Athens imposed on others was finally imposed on itself.
- Mechanisms used against those being subjugated within empire eventually come back to the homeland.
## Two Rules Within Society
- There are two rules within society: one for criminalizing the poor and another for allowing elites to carry out massive acts of financial fraud and orchestrate tax boycotts.
- Nobody works harder than the poor in this country, yet working hard does not guarantee advancement.
# The Decline of the British Empire
Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses the decline of the British Empire due to mismanagement and an elite that was divorced from reality.
## Mismanagement and Elite Separation
- The decline of the British Empire was due to mismanagement and elites separating themselves from the rest of society.
- Elites retreated into their own enclaves, becoming divorced from reality.
- This concentration of power and wealth accelerated the destruction of the system itself.
- John Ralston Saul called it a "coup d'etat in slow motion."
# Eisenhower's Prophetic Warning
Section Overview: Chris Hedges talks about Eisenhower's warning about where America was headed.
## Highest Tax Rates and Military Machine
- Under Eisenhower, highest tax rates for wealthiest individuals and corporations were 91%.
- Destroying the military machine is necessary as it is the greatest enemy of democracy.
# Micro Militarism in Afghanistan
Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses micro militarism in Afghanistan.
## Losing Control
- We lost control of our government and economy.
- Taliban controls more territory than when we went in.
- PKK commander only accepts people who have done their two years military service in Turkish army.
# Neoliberalism's Absurd Notion
Section Overview: Chris Hedges talks about neoliberalism's absurd notion that societies could advance by kneeling before marketplace dictates.
## Unregulated Oligarchic Elite
- Neoliberalism created the absurd notion that societies could advance by kneeling before marketplace dictates.
- No society has benefited from allowing their oligarchic elite to become unregulated and unfettered.
- Corporations used the Lewis Powell memo of 1971 to rollback movements and seize control of institutions.
# Inverted Totalitarianism
Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses Sheldon Wolin's description of the American system as inverted totalitarianism.
## Seizing Control
- The American system is described as inverted totalitarianism.
- Corporations seized control of all institutions, including academia and courts.
# The Role of the Liberal Class in a Capitalist Democracy

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how corporations control everything within the mechanisms of power and how figures who could have warned us were shunted aside. He also talks about how the liberal class functions as a kind of safety valve in moments of distress.
## Figures Who Could Have Warned Us Were Shunted Aside
- Sheldon Wolin was one of those who called out neoliberalism for the con that it is.
- Ralph Nader was another figure who was shunted aside.
- Noam Chomsky, our greatest intellectual hands-down, was also pushed aside.
## The Role of the Liberal Class
- The liberal class functions as a kind of safety valve in moments of distress.
- In a capitalist democracy, you tolerate the liberal class because they set the parameters of acceptable debate.
- As soon as critics on the Left start attacking the structures or motives of ruling elites, the liberal class discredits them and pushes them aside.
- The liberal class can critique excesses but never critiques the system.
## How a Liberal Class Functions in a Capitalist Democracy
- Roosevelt saved capitalism after its collapse in 1930s by creating jobs and Social Security.
- After World War I, there was an assault on radical progressive movements that opened up space in American democracy.
- The system was created as a closed system to avoid direct democracy.
- Mechanisms like electoral college were created to maintain control over democracy.
# Teaching and Incarceration

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about their experience teaching in Rutgers and proposing to teach Gulag Archipelago. They also discuss a phone call they received from the Special Investigations Division of the Department of Corrections of the state of New Jersey regarding a sit-down strike by their students in prison.
- The speaker mentions teaching a class called Conquest where they read books such as Open Veins of Latin America, Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee, and James's Black Jacobins.
- The speaker receives a phone call from the Special Investigations Division of the Department of Corrections regarding a sit-down strike by their students in prison.
- The speaker discusses how the incarcerated men and women knew what would happen to them if they went on strike but still chose to do so.
- The speaker talks about how thousands of men and women carried out work stoppages, commissary boycotts, and hunger strikes throughout the country after the Attica prison uprising.
# Reforming Prisons

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how our system is calcified and that reform will not come from within it. They also talk about how prisoners are paid very little for their labor.
- The speaker states that reform will not come from within our system but only from without.
- The speaker mentions the Free Alabama Movement which did a work stoppage in 2010 to end neo-slavery in prisons.
- Prisoners are paid very little for their labor with some making only four cents an hour in Louisiana or twenty-two cents an hour in New Jersey.
- The speaker talks about how prisoners who work 40-hour weeks for years get out and are not only without Social Security but also in debt.
# Failed Democracy

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how our democracy is not functioning and that appealing to institutions will not bring about change. They also talk about their experience with Bernie Sanders and the Democratic Party.
- The speaker states that our democracy is a failed one.
- The speaker talks about their experience with Bernie Sanders and how he was afraid of being destroyed by the Democratic Party establishment if he defied them.
- The speaker believes that we cannot build a resistance movement within an election cycle.
# Teaching American History and the Three Branches of Government

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about his experience teaching American history and the three branches of government to prisoners. He also discusses how he used Howard Zinn's "A People's History of the United States" to teach his students.
## Teaching American History in Prison
- The speaker submitted a proposal to teach American history and the three branches of government to prisoners.
- He used Howard Zinn's "A People's History of the United States" as a teaching resource.
- The speaker's students were mostly black and were moved by learning about African Americans' stories throughout history.
- The speaker heard his students say, "Damn, we've been lied to," during his lectures on topics such as Reconstruction.
# Corporations' Assault on Democratic Space

Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about corporations' assault on institutions that made democratic space possible. He also discusses how this happened at the same time that the economy was being reconfigured.
## Assault on Democratic Space
- Corporations organized a frontal assault against every institution that made democratic space possible.
- This included mechanisms of reform, giving voice to citizenry and critics of imperialism/capitalism.
- As a result, these spaces closed down at the same time that the economy was being reconfigured.
# Unsustainable System
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about how borrowing money has led to an unsustainable system. He also mentions how tax cuts have contributed to an increase in government debt.
## Unsustainable System
- The speaker talks about how the US is borrowing money to maintain both an empire and a lifestyle that it can no longer afford.
- Tax cuts have led to an increase in government debt, which is not sustainable.
- The speaker mentions a New York Times story on the explosion of government debt, which was quite chilling.
# Elite Universities as Corporations
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about elite universities as corporations. He also discusses how these universities produce systems managers and how humanities are withering away.
## Elite Universities as Corporations
- The speaker talks about how elite universities like Princeton are just overcompensated fund raisers.
- These universities produce systems managers, and computer science is the largest major at both Harvard and Princeton.
- Humanities are withering away, and all mechanisms that teach us not what to think but how to think are disappearing.
# Financial Crash of 2008
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about the financial crash of 2008. He also discusses how China's response was different from that of the US.
## Financial Crash of 2008
- The speaker talks about how systems managers looted the US Treasury to re-inflate a failed financial system after the 2008 financial crash.
- Unlike China's response, which focused on infrastructure projects and putting people to work, $26 trillion were handed out to people who should be in prison.
- CEOs' compensation packages are tied to an overheated stock market, which is not tied to value.
# The Tragedy of Corporate Capitalism
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker discusses how corporations use their power to extract wealth from society and how this has led to a number of social and economic problems.
## Corporate Stock Buybacks
- Corporations buy back their own stock which swells their compensation packages.
- This hoards money that could be used for other purposes such as education or healthcare.
- The fracking industry is an example of a bubble created by projected profit rather than actual profit.
## Economic Inequality
- The healthcare system in the US is inefficient and expensive, with many people going bankrupt due to medical costs.
- Wages have not kept pace with production, leading to 41 million workers earning less than $12 per hour.
- Debt is being used to suppress wages and extract wealth from society.
## Insolvency in Scranton
- Scranton, Pennsylvania faces insolvency due to decimated pension funds caused by financial fraud.
- City assets are being sold off in order to regain financial solvency, leading to higher prices for residents.
## Ecological Crisis
- Unregulated capitalism commodifies everything, including human beings and the natural world.
- Climate change poses a serious threat to humanity, with feedback loops making it difficult to control once temperatures rise beyond certain thresholds.
# The Role of the Christian Right in American Politics

Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses the role of the Christian Right in American politics and how they have acculturated the worst aspects of American imperialism and capitalism into Christianity.
## The Selective Literalism of the Christian Right
- [](t=0:45:07s) The Christian Right are selective literalists who choose certain biblical passages that affirm their ideology.
- They have acculturated the worst aspects of American imperialism and capitalism into Christianity, sacralizing it.
- This is due to the liberal Church not calling them out for who they are, which is Christian heretics.
## Destruction Caused by Clinton Administration
- [](t=0:45:50s) The Christian Right played a part in deindustrialization, slashing social service programs, and other destructive policies during Clinton's administration.
- 70% of original welfare recipients were children.
- Deregulation of FCC allowed corporations to seize control over airwaves.
- Ripping down firewalls between investment and commercial banks precipitated global crisis.
## Faux Liberal Class
- [](t=0:46:44s) There used to be a liberal wing of Democratic Party but it is long gone.
- People continue to speak in feel your pain language but are sold out working men and women.
- This has led to white rage among white working-class people who believe in meritocracy but realize that game is fixed against them.
## Refusing to Address Fundamental Issues
- [](t=0:47:49s) Democrats are playing a dangerous game by refusing to address fundamental issues that have distorted society.
- Pelosi and Schumer funnel Wall Street and corporate money to anointed Democratic candidates while purging Bernie supporters from party.
- Real electoral reform would remove corporate money from Democratic Party.
# Democracy Distorted Our Economic System into an Oligarchy

Section Overview: In this section, Chris Hedges talks about how democracy has been distorted and how the economic system has turned into an oligarchy. He also discusses the Christian Right and their support for Donald Trump.
## The Seizure of Power by a Corporate Cabal
- Democracy has been distorted into an oligarchy.
- Laws and regulations have been rewritten to carry out ecocide for short-term profit.
- The seizure of power by a corporate cabal is similar to that of any cabal, maniacal communist or fascist, which leads to political paralysis.
## The Christian Right's Retreat into Magical Thinking
- The Christian Right has retreated into magical thinking.
- This retreat has created an inability for the government to respond rationally to the needs of the majority of citizens.
- Chris Hedges spent two years writing a book on American fascists, which was his way of trying to reach out to them.
- People in the Christian Right are utterly narcissistic and almost all are white men.
## Support for Donald Trump
- There are long antecedents for the arrival of a monstrosity like Donald Trump, largely coming from the Christian Right.
- Figures who lead the Christian Right are characteristic of Donald Trump.
- They prey on people's despair in much the same way that Trump preys on people who go into his casinos.
# Rise of Trump and the Embrace of the Permanent Lie

Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses how Trump came to power without any ideology, but with the help of Christian fascist ideology. He talks about the decay of civil discourse and the embrace of what Hannah Aaron called "the permanent lie," which is a feature of totalitarian states.
## The Rise of Trump
- Trump has no ideology and rose up out of a decayed state.
- The Christian Right filled the ideological void left by Trump.
- There is a decay in civil discourse that is classic to totalitarianism.
## The Embrace of the Permanent Lie
- The permanent lie is impervious to reality and comes out of the Christian Right.
- All governments lie, but totalitarian states embrace the permanent lie.
- The embrace of the permanent lie creates a kind of collective schizophrenia because reality or verifiable fact is denied.
- Once stability is eradicated, fertile ground for scapegoating, demonizing, and violence is created.
## Sustained Mass Acts of Civil Disobedience
- Our only response now is sustained mass acts of civil disobedience.
- Standing Rock was a model for effective mass acts of civil disobedience that had a spiritual dimension.
- We have no time left just from climate change.
# The Call for Revolution
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker calls for a revolution against the corporate state and draws inspiration from past non-violent revolutions in Eastern Europe.
## The Good Draws to Itself
- The speaker believes that the good draws to itself and that sustained acts of mass civil disobedience can lead to the overthrow of corrupt systems.
- The speaker cites examples of non-violent revolutions in Eastern Europe where a certain segment of the ruling apparatus defected, leading to the downfall of oppressive regimes.
## Personal Experience with Non-Violent Revolutions

- The speaker shares personal experiences covering non-violent revolutions in Eastern Europe, including Honecker's fall from power in East Germany and the renaming of Red Army Square to Jan Palach Square in Prague.
- The speaker recounts how Czech singer Marta Kubišová's song became an anthem during the Velvet Revolution in 1989.
## Fighting Fascism

- The speaker declares that they fight fascism not because they believe they will win but because it is necessary. They believe that corporate forces have their children by the throat and that standing up against them is crucial.
# Changing Democratic Party from Within

Section Overview: In this section, a question is asked about changing the Democratic Party from within, and the speaker shares their thoughts on why this effort may trap progressives and prevent change.
## Trapping Progressives
- The questioner expresses concern about progressives being trapped by efforts to change the Democratic Party from within.
- The speaker agrees with this sentiment and cites Ralph Nader as someone who understands corporate power better than anyone else in America.
# The Importance of Rebuilding Movements
Section Overview: In this section, Chris Hedges discusses the importance of rebuilding movements to pit power against power and protect ourselves from predatory nature.
## Rebuilding Communal Structures
- The press is complicit in creating Trump and we need to rebuild communal structures that allow us to resist.
- We need to rebuild social bonds that allow us to resist and protect ourselves.
- Our job is to put people in power who are looking out the window, like Nixon was during anti-war demonstrations.
## Third Party Politics
- Ralph Nader scared the Democratic Party after 2000, but they responded by demonizing him.
- It doesn't matter who runs for president in 2020.
## Corporate Control
- Corporations are going into prisons and making a killing with services like Global Tel Link Arm Art.
- Half of the people in our prison system are not charged with ever physically harming another person; it's social control.
# The Media's Role in Creating Trump
Section Overview: In this section, Chris Hedges discusses how CNN and other media outlets have created Trump through their endless chatter speculation.
## Endless Burlesque
- CNN is just endless burlesque watch it; it's all reality television.
- CNN has created Trump through their endless chatter speculation.
## Complicity of Corporate Media
- The corporate media loves Trump because he makes them a lot of money.
- The corporate media went along with demonizing Ralph Nader.
## Hyper Individualism
- Hyper individualism is conflated with freedom and is essentially what we are given in place of freedom.
- We need to rebuild communal structures that allow us to resist hyper individualism.
# The System Doesn't Work
Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses the failure of the American political system and the complicity of the Democratic Party in perpetuating social inequality.
## The Failure of the Political System
- The American political system is broken, and there is ample evidence to support this claim.
- The Democratic Party is complicit in perpetuating social inequality because they refuse to address it. They are also resistant to reform because it would threaten their job security.
# Addressing Misinformation in Media
Section Overview: Chris Hedges addresses concerns about his show on RT America and discusses how media outlets can be used to spread misinformation.
## Misinformation in Media
- Chris Hedges' show on RT America has been accused of spreading misinformation by some who view it as a tool of the Russian government.
- Hedges suggests that people should read the Director of National Intelligence report on RT America, which contains seven pages but no mention of Russian propaganda.
- Hedges acknowledges that he knows why Russia funds his show, just as he knew why Voice of America gave voice to Eastern European dissidents during his time working for them.
## Carving Out a Platform for Criticism
- Despite acknowledging that Russia likely funds his show, Hedges maintains that he will not cave and will continue speaking out against imperialism and capitalism wherever he can.
- He believes that it's important to carve out whatever platform you can get and speak with integrity, even if all institutions are inherently demonic according to Paul Tillich.
# Public Broadcasting Systems
Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses the decline of public broadcasting systems and how they have become owned by corporations.
## The Decline of Public Broadcasting
- Public broadcasting systems used to give space and a platform to people who weren't owned, but this is no longer the case.
- NPR is awful, and PBS has become a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Koch brothers. This is why public television has become so boring.
# Conclusion
Section Overview: Chris Hedges concludes his interview by discussing his career as a journalist and his commitment to speaking out against injustice.
## Commitment to Speaking Out
- Chris Hedges left the New York Times because he refused to play their game and was publicly denouncing the call to invade Iraq.
- He will go wherever he can speak out about what he believes in, even if it means working for RT America or other platforms that are viewed as controversial.
- Despite facing opposition throughout his career, Hedges remains committed to speaking out against imperialism and capitalism wherever he can.
# [1:20:10](t=4810s) Mythical Identities and Scapegoating

Section Overview: Chris Hedges discusses how people can retreat into a mythologized version of themselves when they lose their capacity to have a voice within society. This feeds the sense of victimhood, leading to scapegoating and blaming others for problems that are not their fault.
## The Dangers of Scapegoating
- Scapegoating is irrational but effective in demonizing others.
- Elites often use scapegoating as a way to deflect blame from themselves.
- Economic crises can lead to increased scapegoating and demagoguery.
- Trump is a classic demagogue who rose to power by weaponizing existing anger towards the system.
# [1:22:48](t=4968s) Investing with Integrity

Section Overview: Chris Hedges argues that investing with integrity is an oxymoron because capitalism encourages moral fragmentation. He believes that most Americans are not concerned with investing and that ethical investing or philanthropy cannot make up for the immoral aspects of one's lifestyle.
## The Illusion of Ethical Investing
- Capitalism encourages moral fragmentation, making it difficult to invest with integrity.
- Most Americans are not concerned with investing due to low income levels.
- Ethical investing or philanthropy cannot make up for immoral aspects of one's lifestyle.
# [1:24:18](t=5058s) Hope and Giving Children Hope

Section Overview: Chris Hedges does not share the culture's obsession with hope, believing it to be infantile. He suggests that giving children hope involves teaching them about the struggles against oppression throughout history.
## The Problem With Hope
- Hope is infantile and unrealistic in many situations.
- War teaches people to make cold calculations rather than rely on hope.
## Teaching Children About Struggle Against Oppression
- Children should be taught about the struggles against oppression throughout history.
- The people who fight against oppression are brothers and sisters, regardless of their language, color, or country.
# The Fragility of Life
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker talks about how his experiences with death have made him aware of the fragility of life and the importance of standing up for what is just and right.
## Awareness of Life's Fragility
- The speaker has spent a lot of time around death due to losing many people he worked with at a young age.
- He believes that life is brief and fragile, and it is our job to stand up for what is just and right.

- The speaker shares a story about a former student who was wrongly convicted at 14 years old and will not be eligible for parole until he is 70. Despite this, the student remains hopeful and works hard because he wants to become a teacher one day.
# Conclusion
Section Overview: In this section, the speaker concludes his talk by thanking the audience for their questions and inviting them to meet him at his table in the lobby.
## Conclusion
- The speaker thanks Chris Hedges and the audience for their questions.
- He invites everyone to meet him at his table in the lobby where they can pick up a copy of his book.
