div.h2: Gulf stream could collapse as early as 2025, study suggests

span.div: A new study suggests that the Gulf Stream system, known as the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (Amoc), could collapse as early as 2025 if global carbon emissions are not reduced.

This collapse would have catastrophic climate impacts, including disrupting rainfall patterns, increasing storms, dropping temperatures in Europe, and causing rising sea levels on the eastern coast of North America.
The study is based on sea surface temperature data dating back to 1870 and highlights the urgency of reducing emissions to prevent the collapse of Amoc and its devastating consequences.
However, there is still uncertainty about the exact tipping point for Amoc collapse.

div.h2: 'The Climate Change Bomb Has Gone Off,' Says Jay Inslee Amid Extreme Heat

span.div: Washington Governor Jay Inslee, a prominent advocate for climate change action, warned that the "climate change bomb has gone off" amid extreme heat and wildfires across the United States.
Inslee emphasized the urgency of the situation, stating that the consequences of climate change are now at the doorstep.
He praised President Joe Biden's efforts to address climate change but called for further and faster action.

Inslee also criticized Republicans for attempting to repeal climate-focused legislation. Kyle Jones of the Natural Resources Defense Council urged people to vote against politicians who refuse to address the climate crisis.

div.h2: Scientists Decry Human Indifference to 'Probable Sixth Mass Extinction'

span.div: Scientists from the University of Hawai'i and the Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris have published an assessment in the journal Biological Reviews, highlighting the undeniable rate of species loss and the probable sixth mass extinction.
They criticize the reliance on the International Union for Conservation of Nature's Red List, which only covers a small percentage of recognized animal and plant species.
The researchers point to data on molluscs, showing that there are more extinct and possibly extinct species than listed by the IUCN.
The authors express frustration at the lack of political will to address the crisis and call for urgent action.

div.h2: As Climate Shocks Multiply, Designers Seek Holy Grail: Disaster-Proof Homes

span.div: As climate change leads to more extreme weather events, designers are focusing on creating disaster-proof homes to protect against climate shocks.
Geodesic domes and other resilient home designs are gaining attention from climate-conscious home buyers and builders.
However, these innovations have been slow to enter mainstream homebuilding, leaving most Americans vulnerable to climate-related risks.
Resilient homes can be made from steel, concrete, or even traditional wood frames with added protection against hurricanes or flooding.
The costs of building resilient homes can be about 10% higher than conventional construction, but tightening building codes could help bridge this gap.

div.h2: Why tires — not tailpipes — are spewing more pollution from your cars

span.div: Wear and tear on tires and brakes are producing more particle pollution than car exhaust systems.

This problem will worsen as more cars, including heavier electric cars, are on the road. Unlike car tailpipe emissions, brake and tire emissions are not regulated, allowing the pollution to continue unchecked.
In California, brake and tire emissions are the dominant source of traffic pollution. Tests have shown that tires produce about 2,000 times more particle pollution than tailpipes.
The solution may lie in shifting tire materials to natural or non-fossil fuel sources, such as dandelions. Some companies are already experimenting with sustainable tire sources.

div.h2: Where Clarence Thomas Entered an Elite Circle and Opened a Door to the Court

span.div: 1. Clarence Thomas' Horatio Alger induction:
- Clarence Thomas was inducted into the Horatio Alger Association of Distinguished Americans, a club that celebrates meritocratic success and embodies his own life philosophy.
- He moved into the inner circle of the association, where he has become the leading light and granted it unusual access to the Supreme Court.
2. Justice Thomas' wealthy and powerful friends:

- Justice Thomas has received benefits from a broader cohort of wealthy and powerful friends, including major donors to conservative causes with broad policy and political interests and much at stake in Supreme Court decisions.
- His decision not to disclose many benefits for nearly two decades has made it difficult to track potential conflicts of interest.
3. Tasting the good life:
- Justice Thomas' friendships forged through Horatio Alger have brought him proximity to a lifestyle of unimaginable material privilege.
- His Horatio Alger friends have welcomed him at their vacation retreats, arranged V.I.P. access to sporting events and invited him to their lavish parties.
4. Clarence Thomas' origin story:
- Clarence Thomas' origin story begins in a dirt-floor shack in Pin Point, a tiny community founded by formerly enslaved people in the salt marsh lands outside Savannah.
- After a brief spell in a Roman Catholic seminary, he attends the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass., where he is one of a small group of young Black men who integrate the school.
5. New Supreme Court justice:
- Ketanji Brown Jackson is the first Black female member of the Supreme Court.
- She wasted no time in finding her footing, asserting herself in dissents, alliances and questions from the bench.
6. Signs of new caution:
- The Supreme Court remains deeply conservative, but the entire story of its most recent term is considerably more complicated than that of the previous one.
7. Guns case:
- The justices agreed to consider whether the government may forbid people subject to domestic violence orders from having guns.
8. Sunday work case:
- The court broadened protections for religious workers in a case that involved a mail carrier for the U.S. Postal Service who refused to work on his Sabbath.
9. Justice Thomas's early life and career:
- Justice Thomas was one of only 12 Black students in his law school class at Yale, admitted the year the law school introduced an affirmative action plan.
- He felt that his white classmates viewed him as a token, which deepened his belief in the corrosive effects of affirmative action.
- He ended up in Washington, first as a legislative aide to Senator John Danforth of Missouri and then later as the Reagan administration’s chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
10. Justice Thomas's personal life:
- In the mid-1980s, Justice Thomas dated a woman named Lillian McEwen, and they went on a vacation to the Bahamas.
- Not long after they broke up, he met Virginia Lamp, known as Ginni, and they married in 1987.
- Armstrong Williams, a close friend from Justice Thomas’s earliest days in Washington, paid for their wedding reception.
11. Justice Thomas's involvement with the Horatio Alger Association:
- Armstrong Williams came to Justice Thomas's chambers with a plan to restore his spirits, which involved joining the Horatio Alger Association.

- The association has awarded more than $245 million in college scholarships to roughly 35,000 students, and its members have included a wide spectrum of people whose life stories limn the Horatio Alger credo.
- Justice Thomas spends hours meeting privately with scholarship recipients and hosts a ceremony at the Supreme Court every spring.
12. Justice Thomas's use of the courtroom for the Horatio Alger Association:
- Justice Thomas's use of the courtroom for the Horatio Alger Association, while hardly unprecedented, is quite rare.
- Several have said they counted among their proudest achievements having Justice Thomas bestow their Horatio Alger medallions at the Supreme Court.
- This special access and affiliation with Justice Thomas have become central to the identities of the organization and its members.
13. Justice Thomas's feelings about the Horatio Alger Association:
- Armstrong Williams came to have ambivalent feelings about the justice’s involvement in Horatio Alger.
- He loved to see the joy his old friend took in it, especially when working with young people.
- But it also introduced the justice to a “whole different ecosystem” from the Black conservatives with whom he had come up in Washington.
14. Justice Thomas has been celebrated by the Horatio Alger Association:
- The association made him an honorary board member and created scholarships named after his son.
- The scholarships directed money to two Virginia prep schools.
15. Justice Thomas has never been among the wealthier members of the Supreme Court:
- His financial disclosures show he received $1.5 million for his autobiography.
- He also lists income from his wife, a political consultant whose ventures have been underwritten by ideological allies.
16. Justice Thomas is not alone among his colleagues in accepting benefits from rich friends and sympathetic organizations:
- Justice Antonin G. Scalia took 258 subsidized trips from 2004 to 2014.
- Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg disclosed more trips than any other justice in 2018.
17. Justice Thomas gained entree to the lives of some of the wealthy members at the Horatio Alger Association:
- He attended a board meeting at a resort developed on a former sugar plantation in Jamaica.
- He made annual visits to South Florida to help the Dolphins owner pass out scholarships.
18. Justice Thomas and Mr. Sokol have developed a bond beyond Horatio Alger:
- They have enjoyed royal treatment at Cornhuskers football games.
- They have vacationed together in recent years.
19. Mr. Sokol became one of the justice’s most vocal defenders:
- He published an opinion essay in The Washington Times and appeared on Lou Dobbs’s Fox News show.
- He gave a speech at a Connecticut library in which he said the justice had faced “lies, innuendo, distortions and outright personal attacks.”

div.h2: You Call It “Inflation,” I Call It a “Dying Planet”

span.div: This article discusses the current state of inflation and argues that it is a result of climate change and a dying planet.
The author criticizes leaders for ignoring the effects of climate change and failing to address the relationship between rising temperatures and failing harvests.
They predict that resource wars, shortages, and inflation will continue to define the future as the planet continues to deteriorate.
The author also suggests that the true costs of climate change and other global issues have been externalized and not properly accounted for.

div.h2: Putin’s Endgame Is Not a Mystery. It’s Regime Survival.

span.div: The article discusses Putin's endgame in Ukraine and compares it to the wars in Bosnia, Chechnya, and Syria.
It highlights the lessons from the Bosnian conflict, where a leader who embraced violence could remain in power, and an underdog fighting for survival could resist a larger force.
Putin's endgame is to maintain power and return Russia to its perceived lost glory.
However, Ukraine has been preparing for this war and receiving support from the US and NATO allies. The resistance in Bosnia came at a terrible cost, with many deaths and lasting scars.

div.h2: Pumping Groundwater Has Changed Earth’s Spin, Study Finds

span.div: Researchers have discovered that the pumping of colossal amounts of water from underground for agriculture and households has caused Earth's axis to shift.
This is in addition to the accelerated melting of polar ice sheets and mountain glaciers, which also affected the planet's spin.
Groundwater depletion has more than doubled between 1960 and 2000, reaching about 75 trillion gallons per year.
While this shift does not impact the seasons, it does affect satellite-based navigation systems.
Scientists can use data on Earth's axis position from the 20th century to understand shifts in groundwater use before modern data was available.

div.h2: We Need Biodiversity-Based Agriculture to Solve the Climate Crisis

span.div: Biodiversity-based agriculture is necessary to solve the climate crisis.
The Earth's biodiversity has evolved over 4 billion years and can sustain life, but our fossil fuel-based economy has disrupted key climate systems and pushed species to extinction.
Our current industrial agriculture system is unsustainable and only uses a small fraction of the Earth's edible plant species.
Small, biodiverse farms provide more food than large monoculture farms.
To repair the carbon cycle, we need to increase living carbon in plants and soil through biodiversity-based agriculture. We need to recarbonize the world with biodiversity and living carbon.

div.h2: 'People are dying': how the climate crisis has sparked an exodus to the US

span.div: The climate crisis has led to frequent and intense droughts in Central America, causing crop failures and extreme food shortages.
This has forced many to migrate to the US in search of security and a better life for their families.
Guatemala has the sixth-highest malnutrition rate in the world, with at least 47% of children suffering chronic malnourishment.

The impact of climate change on agriculture has made the situation even more precarious for those who depend on it. People are willing to incur crippling debts and risk their lives to migrate, as they see no other option.

div.h2: How the gas industry capitalized on the Ukraine war to change Biden policy

span.div: 1. Gas industry capitalized on Ukraine war to change Biden policy:
- The US gas industry saw an opportunity to push its agenda after the onset of the Ukraine war.
- The industry group LNG Allies sent a letter to the Biden administration with a list of demands, including more drilling on US public lands and the swift approval of proposed gas export terminals.
2. Biden administration changed its rhetoric after the war:
- The Biden administration's rhetoric on climate change 'changed substantially' within just a week of the war.
- Biden's creation of the gas export taskforce was a 'direct response to the proposal put forward by LNG Allies'.
3. LNG as an act of defiance to Putin:
- The embrace of liquified natural gas (LNG) as an act of defiance to Putin has dismayed climate activists.
- Activists warn that it will lock in decades of planet-heating emissions and push the world closer to climate catastrophe.
4. US gas industry was 'licking its lips' at the onset of the Ukraine war:
- The US gas industry was 'licking its lips' at the onset of the Ukraine war.

- Biden's apparent capitulation to the gas industry has opened the door for these companies to continue to profit off the backs of those suffering in Ukraine, those living close to new gas infrastructure in the US and the millions affected by climate change globally.
5. US gas industry notched a number of notable wins since the start of the war:
- The US gas industry wanted six specific gas export applications to be expedited, and within three weeks the US Department of Energy granted two of them.
- By the end of April, two further LNG export licenses had been issued.
6. Gas infrastructure jars with agreed climate goals:
- New gas terminals have a lifespan that is measured in decades, which jars with agreed climate goals.
- The International Energy Agency has said no new fossil fuel infrastructure can be built if the world is to avoid dangerous global heating.
7. Gas drilling produces a large amount of methane:
- Gas drilling produces a large amount of methane, a potent greenhouse gas that is far more effective at trapping heat than carbon dioxide.
- The extraction, transportation and liquefaction required to create LNG for export creates almost as much emissions as burning the gas itself.

div.h2: Arctic Warming Is Happening Faster Than Described, Analysis Shows

span.div: The Arctic is warming four times faster than the global average, and some parts are warming up to seven times faster, according to new research from Finland.
This rapid warming is causing faster melting of the Greenland ice sheet, which contributes to rising sea levels and impacts weather patterns around the world.
The warming is caused by a feedback loop in which melting sea ice exposes more of the Arctic Ocean to sunlight, leading to more warming and melting.
The researchers warn that if the rate of warming continues to increase, the impacts on weather could worsen.

div.h2: US had a strong middle class when the wealthy and corporation were taxed fairly, The GOP plan crushes the middle class

span.div: The U.S. middle class grew after World War II due to economic growth and policies that gave workers more power, but began to decline in the 1980s as the government took the side of business over workers by lowering taxes on corporations and the rich, reducing regulations, and allowing firms to grow through mergers and acquisitions.
The Republican tax plan doubles down on these policies, which have caused the decline of the middle class.
While Republicans claim the plan will raise wages, companies have indicated they will mainly use their savings to benefit wealthy owners of corporate stock.

div.h2: Colorado River: Where the West quenches its thirst

span.div: The Colorado River, which supplies water to much of the western United States, is chronically overallocated and overused, with 70% of its water diverted for agriculture.
The river's delta in Mexico has largely dried up, and the basin has been ravaged by extreme drought since 2000, intensified by climate change.

div.h2: Trump's tax policy gifted 18 Billion dollars to big banks #structuralchange #voteblue
div.span: This is an obvious example of Republican socialism. Using the power of government to transfer wealth from people to big corporations. This is what we must fight. Most of us are victims of this wealth transfer

div.h2: They say the rich give to charity, this post says some just pretend and hide their money
div.span: Trickle down economics is a fantasy. Here we learn that the founder of google is skipping on his charitable donations which is required by law. We learn that the Larry Page foundation finds accounting gimmicks to pretend they are giving to charity while they park their money. We need structural change to fix our economy and our society.

div.h2: These 91 Fortune 500 companies didn't pay federal taxes in 2018
div.span: We all pay taxes for the common good, this means national defense, national security, social security, roads, public schools and more. Under Donald Trump the richest corporations have been relieved of this responsibility. This is socialism for the rich.

div.h2: Most Medical Bankruptcies happen to the Middle class - we need structural change

span.p: Our healthcare system is not working when 62% of all bankruptcies in the united states are due to medical expenses.Most medical debtors were well educated, owned homes and had middle class occupations. Medicare for all will address and solve this problem. We need structural change

div.h2: History tells us all about Trump and his style of leadership
div.span: If we don't learn from history we are doomed to repeat it. The rise of populist around the world is not new. Every time life gets tough, populist strong men take advantage of people's vulnerabilities for their own short sighted gains! People with extreme views need to be reminded of the consequence of their beliefs. This post was written before Trump was elected and much of it is proven true by this point of Trump's presidency

div.h2: Corporate ownership of Media is hurting our democracy
div.span: Well informed people will make the right decisions. Unfortunately in our country today we have 5 major corporations who report news based on their corporate interest and their bottom line, instead of facts and real sentiment. We need structural change.

div.h2: Republicans cut taxes for the rich, but want to call services for everyone else
div.span: Republican policy is to give a hand out to the rich and then cut entitlements for the middle class and working poor. This is a game that has been played many times over the years. This in reality is socialism for the rich and corporations.

div.h2: Under Trump the deficit has doubled - He doesn't know how to manage the economy
div.span: We need to make sure people we elect understand how government and economy works. We learn from this article that Trump wants to reduce the deficit, without touching programs like medicare, or cutting military spending, while he wants to build infrastructure. Republicans are conflicted because their rhetoric doesn't meet reality.

div.h2: Trump wants socialism for the rich, while cutting children's healthcare services
div.span: Donald Trump and the republican congress cut taxes for the rich, and now that they have to pay for it they are cutting vital healthcare services to children and the affordable care act. When Republicans and conservatives are in charge we have socialism for the rich!

div.h2: Vermont's experiment in Medicare for all shows us that the program needs to be implemented nationally
div.span: The lessons learned from Vermont is that first we need to take cost under control and second a single state will have a hard time on its own because people work across state lines and the federal government needs to be involved to make it work. Candidates need to articulate their approach!
